*S.S. Osmanieh, Thursday 11 a.m. May 9, 23, June 6 and 20.

Fast steamers Assouan, Minieh, and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA calling fortnightly at LARNACA (Cyprus) and continuing from BEYROUT in alternate weeks to RHODES, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, DARDANELLES, GALLIPOLI and CONSTANTINOPLE.

div.head: NATIONALIST HISTORY.
div.p: The youth of Egypt is learning a strange form of history from its guides, so strange that one is convinced that the present generation will witness the birth of quite a number of myths. Some have indeed made their appearance- e.g. the Denishwai myth, the myth relating to the resignation of Lord Cromer-- though this last off-spring of the Goddess Credulity shows signs of succumbing to infantile decay while others have been revived both by the Egyptian Nationalists and their opponents, e.g. the myth of Arab superiority to the Turk, the myth of "Islamic civilisation, the myth of the Arab military virtues, the myth of the Arab descent of the majority of the Egyptians, and the myths concerning European aggression at the expense of the Moslem nations of the west. The last is certainly the most widespread, and the most plausible and it is on that account that we will deal with it first.

The Arab conquests of the first two centuries of the Moslem era were carried out by bands of fervent proselytisers (with a taste for plunder and a penchant towards the fair sex) chiefly at the expense of the Byzantine and Persian monarchies and the Christian and Zoroastrian religions ; they were only successful owing to the fact that the two great empires were exhausted by the long and terrific struggle between Heraclius and Chosroes, and that the old Western Empire (where the Roman element predominated as a civilising force, though the races were as mixed as in the Eastern Empire) had fallen to pieces before the assaults of the northern barbarians. The Arab conquest had, none the less, an immense importance to Europe. It tore from the hands of European masters and European civilisation, the provinces of Syria, Egypt, North Africa and Spain. It completely wiped out all vestiges of Christianity in the African provinces west of Egypt and it practically destroyed the Roman organisation, the 'machine of government from Urfa to the Pyrenees. Its sole justification was the vigour and energy displayed by the conquerors, which saved them from the consequences of their own lack of organisation. Religious fervour, courage and dash, triumphed for a time over a higher organisation unimbued with the enthusiasm necessary for success, or over barbarian enemies who lacked the Roman discipline and the Moslem faith and had, moreover, been softened by the relaxation of manners and morals that followed victory. Roderick the Visigoth was a very poor match for Tarik the Berber, but without being too partial, one may reasonably contend that the Moslem conquerors would have won at best but Pyrrhic victories against the Gothic host that annihilated the Eastern legions at Adrianople or the armies of Alaric or Clovis. This contention is supported by the failure of the 'Saracens' in France, in Italy and in Asia Minor. In Italy though they conquered Sicily and Calabria, they were unable to extend their conquests to the north. In France they were never a real menace after the victory of Charles the Hammer, and in Asia Minor, though they might raid and harry the frontiers they never effected any permanent conquests after the overthrow and death of Said el Ghazi el Battal at the hands of Leo the Isaurian at Akroệnos.

The conquests of the Arabs were based upon the principle that might is right.' The Arab who had fought at Kadesiya or Wadi Yarmouk believed that his canse was just, that the Divine blessing hallowed his exploits, that it was the will of God that he should prevail. He did not even consider the Byzantine or Persian case. Similarly the invaders of France never asked themselves whether the Franks and Gauls were likely to accept Islam, whether they were not justified in resisting plunderers and conquerors and in refusing tribute. The Arab fought firstly for his personal pleasure and advantage. Salvation, plander, a well stocked harem in this world and the houris in the next--and secondly, subconsciously perhaps, for the triumph of Islam and Islamic ideas. Is this explanation of his motives too materialistic Hardly, for we write of the average Arab whom we consider to have been and to be as human as any other warrior of the past. Religious fervour and material advantage went hand in hand, as they did in the case of the Crusader, who, having conceived a notion that robbery under arms, superior piracy in fact, was sanctioned by Heaven when committed at the expense of Infidels,' fought with a fervour that was seldom accompanied by a knowledge of tactics or by the display of the vulgarest common-sense. In fact, it might be urged that the more civilised a nation becomes the more idealistic are its armies.

The average European and Japanese soldier fights because he has in him the conviction that he must sacrifice his comfort and if necessary his life to the State. It is idle to contend that he has no choice, for if the majority of civilised men were Tolstoyans, armies and wars would come to an end. As it is he fights for the 'fatherland' i.e. in the interest, real or supposed, of the State, its institutions, its religion or ideals, and its safety, and the more convinced he is of the excellence of these institutions, and ideals, the better he will fight. As for the question of "right" and "wrong," we doubt whether these concepts have ever guided the rulers or the people of any nation when the national security or ideals have been threatened, or even questioned. From the point of view of the logician there was a good deal to say for the Boer case in 1899, but the mass of the English people realised more or less clearly that they were about to put the question--is S. Africa to be under the Union Jack or the Vierkleur To the trial of battle. Similarly the conquerors of Algeria, Saracens or Frenchmen, as far as they considered the question at all, believed themselves to be absolutely justified in making conI quests at the expense of the inhabitants of the country. They believed in their civilisation, their religion, or their institutions, sufficiently to be ready to enforce them upon others against their will. The more vigorous the inner life of a state or a people, the more expansive are its energies and the more thorough its conquest, and the European expansion in the 19th century at the expense of the western Moslems is an exact parallel to the Moslem expansion in the 7th century at the expense of the Roman Empire. Here we find the justification-if any were needed-of the "aggressions" of Europe in the Medi terranean. These wars of conquest are in reality "wars of reconquest". The heirs of the civilisation of the Empire; Gauls, Britons, Iberians, Italians, have won back for their civilisation -- the lineal descendant of the classical culture-the province lost in the confusion of the dark ages, by conquest, occupation or protectorate : the methods vary, but the end has been the same. If, therefore, the Moslems of Egypt or North Africa complain of the aggressions of the European powers or deplore the excess of Imperialism, they should at least have the honesty to admit that the heirs of Greek and Roman civilisation have but reoccupied the territories once lost to the aggressive imperialism of the Arabs, which though inspired by courage and zeal, never proved itself capable of creating a stable political system in the place of that which it so. suddenly destroyed. The Arabs of N. Africa, Tunis, Algeria and Morocco, had for 1100 years the opportunity of building up a well organised state or states. They failed under the Caliphs and when the Caliphate had loosened its hold on N. Africa, they failed again to produce anything better than dynasties of barbarous and often fanatical conquerors Almohades, Almoravides, Aghlabites,or bands of pirates whose empire was finally destroyed to the great satisfaction of all the dwellers on the North coast of the Mediterranean. We are quite ready to grant that the Sallee rovers who sacked Baltimore near Cork, and even reached Iceland, were hardy and adventurous fellows--90 are hornets, highwaymen, panthers, and other predatory beings. But we refuse to admit that no one has any right to attempt to destroy these picturesque but dangerous creatures. Those who justly complain of aggression must never have been aggressive, and the historian must search the history of mankind with superhuman diligence and microscopic vision, if he is to find one example of a tribe, a community, a nation or a religion that has never committed a single act of aggression against its neighbours. Were there such a tribe, nation, or religion, the sole trace of it which he would discover would be its obituary notice, for the Greek saying 'Polemos patêr pantôn' is as true of human institutions as of the animal world, whether 'war, the father of all things' be waged with the bayonet or with the ballot box.

div.head: Amateur Race Meeting
div.p: The Alexandria Sporting Club announce an amateur race meeting for Saturday, the 15th inst. Entries will close at 6 p.m. on Tuesday next, and will be published in the following day's papers. Measuring day will be Tuesday next at 3.30 p.m. and starting declarations must be made in writing before 5 p.m. on *Friday the 14th inst. Six entries in each race - must be received, otherwise the race will not take place. All jockeys must be amateurs.

div.head: Fire at Moharrem Bey.
div.p: Yesterday evening at about eleven o'clock a fire broke out in a paper factory belonging to Mr. Lagoudakis at Moharrem Bey. The fire brigade, under the command of Superintendent Waller, on receiving the alarm made all haste to the spot, but owing to the distance they had to go the fire had made considerable headway before their arrrival. Though the fire was soon got under control, it was not until six o'clock this morning that the brigade were able to leave the building. The fire is believed to have been due to spontaneous combustion, and has involved the destruction of 200 tons of paper - and 60 tons of rags. The loss is covered by insurance.

div.head: The French Fete
div.p: Energetic preparations are being made by the committee appointed to superintend the arrangements for celebrating the French Nat. jonal Fêté, to be held on the 14th July. If-one may judge by the interest with which the residents of Cairo have been discussing the coming event, the complete success of the commemoration of the establishment of a Republic in France should be already assured. Tomorrow evening the committee intend to hold another meeting, to consider offers received in respect to the decoration and illumination of the Esbekieh Garden, which excellent position has been again placed at their disposal by the Egyptian authorities; but, we understand, that certain reservations have been made in regard to firework displays and more especially relative to the use of rockets.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie).

La baisse continue, peu considérable, il est vrai, mais presque générale. Les affaires, peu nombreuses, ont porté principalement sur l'United, les Estates, la Salt and Soda, la Port Said Salt et la Cassa di Sconto. On attend avec impatience l'entrée en scène du Consortium qui par son intervention pourra ramener la confiance et peut-être la hausse. S'il faut en croire les bruits qui circulent, le délégué commencerait ses opérations dans le courant de cette semaine.
Malheureusement pour notre place l'argent redevient cher. Le taux de la banque est renseigné à 34 et le taux privé à 3. soit en hausse respective de $ sur les prix d'hier.
L'Agricole fléchit à 8 5/16, la National Bank à 22 1/2, et la Delta Light à 9 7/8.
Tandis que les actions Eaux du Caire regagnent i fr. à 118, les parts de jouissance perdent encore 8 fr. à 215.
Plus faible aussi la Daïra à 14 13/16, les Dividendes Bière d'Alexandrie à 110, la Nile Land à 20, les Lots Tures à 154, la Cassa à 162 et 161.
En revanche, l'obligation nouvelle Crédit Foncier reprend à 268, la Banque d'Athènes à 1926, le Comptoir à 3 5/8 l'ancienne et 3 7/16 la nouvelle. .

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Cotton Mills sont ramenés à 3/9, la Salt & Soda à 19, la Delta Land à 2 1/4, les Estates à 1 1/4, les Building Lands à 3, l'Aboukir à 32, la Port Said Salt à 17, l'United à 19/32, les Ritz à 15/16, la Land Inv. & Building a 1/2, ainsi que l'Arditi.
Sur le reste il n'y a pas de changement à signaler, les affaires ayant été nulles.

London, Wednesday.
The "Temps" states that the Abyssinian Railway Company is unable to meet Coupons bonds due, and have suspended payment.

The French Envoy at Abyssinia has been instructed to see to measures it is expedient to take for the preservation and exploitation of the part of the line already built. Also to look after negotiations pending with King Menelik concerning the projected extension of the line to Addis Abeba.

After 15 days hearing the important divorce petition of Bryce v Bryce and Pape has been dismissed.

div.head: COLLAPSE OF A HUT.
div.p: As we go to press we are informed that a native hut in Rue Ibrahim, Minet-el-Bassal quarter, collapsed at noon to-day. Four natives were buried underneath, but were immediately extracted by the fire brigade, and are still alive although severely injured. They have been taken to the hospital by the Society "Soccorsi d'Urgenza."

div.head: DISTRICT POST OFFICES.
div.p: We have at different periods, as well as several of the local papers, called attention to the urgent need of a district post office for the important quarter of Ismailieh in Cairo, which together with the adjacent quarters of Tewfikieh, Kasr el-Nil and Bab el-Louk, comprise the best residential parts of the capital, and in which are situated all the banks, commercial companies and leading firms. These combined I must have a population approximately at least 150,000 inhabitants and the nearest post office at present is the one at Ataba-el-Khadra, quite two miles from Kasr el-Nil or Tewfikieh. The postal administration has opened district offices in far less important parts of the capital, for example at Faggalla, Bab-el-Khalk and Nasrieh and we think it is high time that steps should be at once taken to remedy this deficiency for the quarters that require a district office far more than any of the latter.

div.head: BONAPARTE IN EGYPT.
div.p: Some little time ago we referred to the approaching publication of a new work on Egypt which a well-known London publisher has announced. We now learn that this work will be issued towards the end of this month and that it will appear as "Bonaparte in Egypt and the Egyptians of to-day." The author is Mr. H. A. Browne, who for over thirty years has been known far and wide in the East as a staunch advocate of English interests, and one who has a more intimate acquaintance with the life of the East than any other European. From Calentta to Constantinople and thence to Cape Town, Mr. Browne has travelled far and long, and always as an Eastern, and so thoroughly has his incognito, for it cannot be described as a disguise, been maintained that more than once he has had great difficulty in establishing his real character. Thus at Tiflis the Rusian officials refused to accept his English passports, insisting upon recording him as an Arnout or Albanian Mahomedan and much to his discomfort treating him accordingly. Again at Constantinople he had to face the same difficulty, the officials there even going so far as to arrest him and change him with travelling with false passports. He was more fortunate at Astrabad in Persia, where the Russian Consul while refusing to grant him a visa on his English passports gave him a new passport describing him as "believed to be of Turkish origin." Even in India, native officials, who might be supposed to have a very keen scent for the detection of an Englishman whatever character he might choose to adopt, have more than once insisted upon treating him as an oriental. With such an experience of the East to guide him it would be strange if any. thing that Mr. Browne has to say about the East should not be worth hearing.

div.head: THE LOST DÉTACHMENT
div.p: NATIONALIST CRITICS.

We hear on good authority that the sad loss of the Sudanese patrol in the Western Desert, between Dongola and the Arbani road, was entirely due to the fact that the party left the Bir Natron wells for Abou Tabari, where there is a good water supply, under the conduct of a guide who declared that he knew the road, but none the less lost his way, and only admitted his mistake when the unfortunate patrol hard exhausted their water supply, which was quite sufficient to last for the whole journey from Natron to Abu Tabari had the guide only known the road. We believe that these localities are from 100 to 150 miles E. of the Nile and are therefore not in such easy reach of the telegraph as our Nationalist critics, who are of course making all the capital they can make out of the incident, pretend. The insinuation that the men were sent without guides into the desert is absurd. Were this the custom of the military authorities in the Sudan they would soon have no troops left! The days when an Egyptian war vessel searched the Mediterranean in vain for Malta and returned with the news "Malta mafeesh" are past. Then there was no press to expose the mismanagement which could lead to so comic and so humiliating an incident. Now the mistake of a Inckless guide, which seems to have cost him his life is brought up against the War Office and the Sudan Government by their self appointed critics, who having never done any desert work on camels, do not realise the dangers that beset the best equipped expeditions.

div.head: PRESS OF EGYPT.
div.p: INTERESTING STATISTICS.

Artin Pasha contributes an interesting articles to the "Bulletin de l'Institut Egyptien" giving the statistics of the Press in Egypt up to the end of 1904. According to this article there were in 1839 two newspapers, one in Arabic and one in Turkish, in 1868 there were 3 French, 2 Italian, 1 Arabic and Turkish and 1 Arabic journal; in 1889 15 Arabic, 8 French, 1 English-French, 4 Italian and 5 Greek; and in 1904 the figures were as follows:-Arabic 118, French 17, French-English 3, Italian 6, Greek 15, French-English-Arabic 2, English 3, Hebrew 1, French-Arabic 1, English-Arabic 1, - Italian-Arabie 1, ItalianFrench 2, Armenian 3, and Turkish 3. Of the journals being published at the end of 1904; 29 were daily, 4 three times a week, 6 twice a week, 76 weekly, 24 twice a month, and 37 monthly. Of the 33 papers published in 1889 only 16 continued to 1904.

div.head: JEWISH COLONISATION IN THE SUDAN
div.p: According to the Jewish World" M. Galante, a Cairo gentleman of the Jewish persuasion, is at work on a great scheme which, "should it be carried into execution, will render important services to our co-religionists from Russia and Roumania who come to this country. This scheme is one of Jewish colonisation in the Sudan, and with facts to support his contention M. Galante shows that this. region, which is practically an English colony, offers a vast field for agricultural and commercial industries. Some philanthropie societies and eminent co-religionists are in constant correspondence with M. Galante, and are discussing with him the question of sending a commission to the Sudanto study its topography, climate, etc. Anybody who knows the territory watered by the Nile will, without doubt, recognise its suitability for the object just mentioned."

div.head: COTTON MILLS OF JAPAN.
div.p: At the annual general meeting of the Kobe Board of Trade the President remarked that the cotton mills of Japan during 1906 had a most successful year, their production being sold out for some months ahead almost all the year round. The Canadian Commercial Agent at Yokohama reports that large dividends were earned by the better class of spinning mills, and a considerable increase of spiules would be made this year. Prices of yarns dropped somewhat in the summer months, but advanced towards the end of the year. The quantity exported was some 1,000 piculs (1 picul equals 133lb,) less than for 1905, though the value shows an increase of 1,500,000 yen. The market generally was in a very healthy condition,and with a good demand from China on account of the increase in the price of silver, mills generally are in a most flourishing condition, and one or two have made arrangements for an increase of capital. From another source the Canadian Commercial Agent states that the cotton-spinning industry, which made considerable progress after the JapanChina War,does not indicate so great a relative expansion under the influence of the present speculative mania as some other industries. He goes on to say that the demand for cotton yarn and cotton cloth for home consumption, is increasing year after year, and the export, mainly to the Asiatic mainland, is also increasing. In all respects there is an assurance felt that new companies have a promising future.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss "liner "Menes" arrived at Liverpool on Monday.
The Papayanni liner "Avon" sailed last night for Liverpool with 3.482 bales Egyptian cotton, and 334 bales Syrian cotton, and 1,254 bags onion.

div.head: CAIRO BUILDING SITES.
div.p: NO FALL IN PRICES

A correspondent writes:- There seems to be an idea that prices of building sites in the better residential districts of the Capital are falling, or that we may expect a drop in the near future, but such an idea is altogether fallacious, and not borne out by facts, for sites. suitable for building purposes have, on the contrary, been steadily increasing all the winter, and even at this moment there is only a momentary lull, which is usual at the dull season of the year, but no relapse from former values is apparent from the recent sales. For example, a plot belonging to the Société Immobilière in the Sharia Kasr-el-Nil changed hands a short time back at L.E. 36 the square metre, whilst for another plot, known as the Maison Borelli, in Sharia Soliman Pasba, no less than L.E. 40 is being asked. Lots on the property formerly belonging to the Prince Mohamed Ali, opposite the Savoy Hotel, cannot be had at this moment under L.E. 50 to L.E. 60 the metre. There is a momentary suspension also in the active negotiations prevailing during the past winter season for land in the favorite suburbs-such as Gkezireh, Kasr el-Aly, Kasr-el-Doubara, and those of the Matarieh line--but this was to be expected, and doubtless in the coming autumn, dealings will be as brisk as before in these directions for the good reason that as the population by immigration or otherwise, and I rentals in the city keep at their present figures people are compelled to seek house accommodation at reasonable prices elsewhere. This is likewise shown by the number of new hotels that are in contemplation in the immediate suburbs, for those already existing in the town are so crowded during the height of the season that numbers of visitors are turned away daily, so great is the demand for rooms and suites.

div.head: SHIPPING MOVEMENTS.
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT),

Suez, Tuesday. The Messageries Maritimes steamer "Kouangsi," from Japan arrived at Suez this morning with a breakdown in her machinery, and was towed through the Canal by the tug "Titan." She however came to Suez without assistance.
Owing to the S.W. monsoon having begun in the Indian Ocean, all steamers are arriving a day or two late. The R M.S. "Ortona" which entered the Canal on Sunday last was up to her time.

div.head: THE INDUSTRIES OF GAZA.
div.p: British Consular-Agent Kneşevich, in a trade report says that Gaza is situated in the south-east of Palestine and is only about 12 miles to the north of Rafah, which marks the Turco-Egyptian boundary. It is the commercial and administrative centre of all the surrounding villages and for many of the Bedouin tribes, who pitch their tents in the plains. The population of Gaza numbers about 40,000, while that of the surrounding villages is about 70,000. The principal occupation of the people is agriculture ; only a small minority are occupied in trade and commerce. During the summer months Gaza is very busy. numbers of people being employed in the export of barley, which is the chief product of the district. In 1906, owing to the lateness and irregularity of the rains, the barley crop was less plentiful than in 1905, and only 12 ship-loads were taken against 26 ship-loads in the previous year. Wheat, millet, and most of the fruits and vegetables of Palestine are also produced at Gaza. The manufactures of the place are limited to native necessaries, such as a rough and primitive kind of pottery, cotton garments, and sieves: Thus, with the exception of grain, vegetables, and cattle, nearly everything has to be imported. Merchants and traders import all their goods from Beirut and Jaffa, either by sea on lighters or by land on camels. The long-talked-of jetty was at length completed on December 8, 1906. It is only 60 mètres long by 8 mètres in width, and is not of much use for the shipment of barley. 'A custom-house was built on the beach at the beginning of the year. A police station and a public garden were begun, but owing to lack of funds the work stopped and the site is offered for sale. The roads from Gaza to Jaffa and Beersheba are badly in need of repair. Beersheba, which was rebuilt five years ago, is growing steadily. During the year a mosque was built there and a public garden laid out. One of the ancient wells was opened and á pump placed on it to supply the town with water,

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in the spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: AT THE RACES.
div.p: To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN Gazette."

Sir.- From the recent correspondence in your columns, it appears, as is usually the case upon such a subject as this, that the question of "undesirable woman" visiting the races, is creating undeserved publicity. As a matter of fact until the appearance of this correspondence, although I have been present at practically every race meeting at the Sporting Club this season, the "evil" referred to by "Paterfamilias" and an "Irate Husband" has failed to attract my notice. True my only object in going to the races is, as should be and I believe is, in the majority of cases, for the sport of the thing, and I may be no connoisseur in the art of discriminating the black sheep" from the "white": this I prefer to leave to "Paterfamilias" andan "Irate Husband", since from their observations this occupation appears of more interest to them than the racing. May I also ask your two correspondents whether they have seen any act of molestation, or anything approaching unbecoming behaviour on the part of the women referred to: if so then my powers of observation sadly need sharpening. I do not wish to occupy too much of your valuable space, but while on the subject it also occurs to me to mention that if your correspondents had raised any objection to the glaring evil of the Boulevard de Ramleh as soon as dusk sets in, when molestation is the rule rather than the exception, they might have met with some support, but their present complaint seems to me groundless. I entirely agree with "A RaceGoer" that so long as the "members' enclosure" is made public, then no discrimination can be made, and if members wish only to associate with their own"select" clique, then they must be "penned" off in their own enclosure, and let the general public look after themselves.
Yours truly,
"SPORTSMAN."
Alexandria, June 4, 1907.

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF TAE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
div.p: Sir.-In reply to the letter of "Paterfamilias" and "Irate husband" I think I must side with "Don Juan" and advise the irate husbands to install themselves at the entrance of the racecourse, so as to be able to sort the race goers. Here in Alexandria everybody must admit that it is a very difficult thing to draw the line as to who are the black and who are the white sheep of the fold, Moreover I fail to see how one could prevent the "Un desirables" going to the race course when the same persons are admitted to theatres, cinematograph halls and all other public places.
Yours truly,
IMPARTIAL.
Alexandria, June 5 1907.

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
div.p: Sir.--Very many people must welcome the letter of the other day signed "Paterfamilias" calling attention to the scandal of the Alexandria Race Course. The grounds are private property kept up by the members, who are therefore quite at liberty to decide who may or who may not be admitted. The committee should therefore be called upon to take immediate action, as members will not continue to support a parade for the demi-monde, whose presence deters many people, members amongst others, from attending the races.
Yours truly,
EXCLUDED
San Stefano, June 4, 1907.

div.head: WANTED A TUB.
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir, - "Paterfamilias " and the "Irate Husband " have raised a very amusing controversy in your paper. Have those gentlemen ever been on a race course outside Alexandria. There are one or two of us here who have seen the derby,and have also attended race meetings at Auteiul and Longchamps. We went to see the races and to put on our humble dollar or a pound if we were lucky, and I haven't met any one who passed a sleepless night on account of the moral aspect of the people he met on the course or courses. As an easy way out of the difficulty let me humbly suggest that & committee be appointed at once, that delegates attend the turnstiles, and that no one of the weaker sex be admitted to the Alexandria race course unless able to produce. at least two responsible references. There are a lot of people who go through life looking for trouble and I think "Paterfamilias" and the "Irate Husband" belong to that number. The writer knows the East as far as the Philippines and he has never seen a better behaved Eastern town than Alexandria at night, or a better conducted race meeting than we have here.
"Paterfamilias" is keener sighted than most of us : personally I see a lot of exceptionally well dressed women and there it ends.
Your's truly
"DIOGENES."

div.head: PRO BONO PUBLICO.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN "GAZETTE."

Sir, ---It is with great interest that I read she two letters by Mr. W. T. Emmens under the above mentioned heading, which recently appeared in your valuable paper. Let me bring to your notice that a petition signed by me and many inhabitants of the quarter) live in (Marina), has been duly sent to the Municipality with the purpose of having these open grills replaced by the sanitary system Plesch, which I noticed in the principal thoroughfares of our town. The sewer gas escaping from those open grills contaminates the air continually to the detriment of the shopkeepers of the Rue Franque and Marina, and is of a dangerous character to all pedestrians passing through these streets. Of the many requests for the Plesch siphon from many private people, as I have been given to understand, none of these have ever been taken into serious consideration by the Municipal authorities. Thanking you in advance for the protection of our common interests.
I am, Sir, Your obedient servant.
A PETITIONER OF THE MARINA QUARTER.
Alexandria, Jane 3 1907.

div.head: GREAT EGYPTIAN DICTIONARY.
div.p: Before the Berlin Academy of Science the other day Prof. Adolf Erman, the well-known Egyptologist, reported the progress made on the Dictionary of Egyptology, the mammoth effort of the German scientific world. The material gathered in the last nine years has been sifted and is now ready for editing.

Prof. Erman declares that it is not his aim to produce a finished book similar to "Thesaurus Linguae Latinae" for Egyptian philolog. ists. The object of the new dictionary is to enable the student to translate Egyptian texts without being compelled to depend upon guesswork. Much has been accomplished toward formulating a grammar during the last three decades, and it is hoped that similar results may attend the attempt to define and classify the vocabulary.

It is a mistake, however, Prof. Erman continues, to indulge in false illusions. Just as the grammar offered a comparatively limited knowledge of the rules governing verbal expression, so the vocabulary most of necessity leave much to be desired. There are a million words, some permanent, some transitory, in many forms and expressing many shades of meaning, the true definitions of which can only be reached by infinite comparison aided by an endless process of exclusion.

div.head: DÉLÉGATION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie hier après-midi sous la présidence de Schiess Pacha.
-Elle a pris connaissance de l'avis favorable du Comité des travaux publics au sujet du règlement sur les constructions, qu'elle a adopté.

Elle a fait ressortir, toutefois, que ce nouveau règlement ne doit pas être appliqué seulement aux nouvelles constructions, mais aussi aux anciennes dont le remaniement est décidé par les propriétaires.
Ce règlement sera approuvé aujourd'hui par la Commission.
- La Délégation a pris note d'une lettre du Ministère de l'Intérieur demandant /quelle suite a donné la Municipalité à la question des maisons à bon marché.
- Elle a décidé l'aménagement d'une place an quartier Labbane.

- La Délégation a longuement examiné la question de la ventilation des égouts et a pris connaissance d'un rapport de l'Ingénieur en chef à ce sujet, ainsi que d'un projet de système de ventilation, que la Délégation à décidé d'adopter à titre d'essai. Elle a demandé à l'Ingénieur en chef de lui soumettre un devis pour ces essais.
- La Délégation a autorisé la dépense nécessaire pour l'élargissement d'une route à l'Ibrahi-10 mieh, moyennant contribution par moitié de la dépense, de la part de l'Areolonite Company Limited,
-Elle a adjugé à M. Di Bari pour la somme de 1154 livres les travaux de dallage de la rne Gebel Zeitoun an Gabbari.
- Les offres présentées pour la fourniture de 20,000 mètres carrés de dalles ont été renvoyées aux services pour rapport.
La séance a été levée à 7 h. 30 du soir.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION
div.p: SECTION COTONNIERE.
RÉSUMÉ DES RÉPONSES REÇUES EN MAI 1907. No. 174

Les plaintes ont été générales au sujet des fraicheurs qui ont régné pendant la première moitié du mois ; mais, depuis quinze jours la température est favorable et la jeune plante se développe d'une façon normale.
On espère aussi qu'avec la continuation de la chaleur actuelle, une partie du retard admis par nos correspondants pourra être regagnée.
Les réensemencements sont terminés depuis une dizaine de jours et, comme dit dans notre I précédent rapport, ils ont été moins nombreux que l'année passée.
L'eau est partout suffisante.
Des apparitions isolées et insignifiantes de vers ont été signalées ; mais grâce aux mesures prises pour leur destruction immédiate, ils n'ont en définitive causé presque aucun degat.
De la Haute-Egypte et du Fayoum, lored sei gnements sont satisfaisants, quoique, aussi, la récolte soit en retard de deux semaines
Pour le Comité
Le Président en fonction
P. FENDERL.
Alexandrie, le 31 Mai 1907.

div.head: TRADE OF CYPRUS.
div.p: (Continued from May 27, 1907). It must not be imagined from the preceding observations that Cyprus is a land suited more to gardening than to farming. We have already referred to her wine and corn. In ancient days she was known as the "Grânary of the East," and although times have changed she still continues year after year to lay down a large part of her soil to cereal crops. Of these barley is the most extensively grown and every year the best of it goes to Messrs. Bass and Co. for malting purposes. The old-fashioned methods of husbandry employed account for the comparatively small yields per acre, but modern ploughs and other agricultural implements are being adopted more and more and the use of these, together with a more enlightened system of rotation in place of alternate cropping and fallowing, should give more abundant' returns.

The market for Cyprus corri has been much restricted owing to the large percentage of dirt, stones, etc. when it generally contains, due to the primitive method of threshing on the "aloni," or threshing floor. This state of things is now being remedied: the Government has imported winnowing machines for sifting and cleaning the tithe corn, and several merchants are now doing the same with their corn for export. Then again an increasing quantity of corn is yearly passed through threshing machines, which are becoming gradually better understood. .

Corn farming in Cyprus is, however, on the point of undergoing an important change. The tremendous rise in wages which has taken place during the last 4 or 5 years, touches no class of the community more directly than the farmers : and this, more than any other fact is bringing about the introduction of labour saving machinery of various kinds. That which years of persuasion and demonstration have failed to accomplish will now be brought about by this forcible appeal to the farmer's pockets. What with the use of modern ploughs, reaping machines, steam threshers, and a regular system of proper rotation, we may confidently expect to find a larger area of land annually under corn a heavier yield per acre, and a cleaner sample offered for sale. If this come about, Egypt should become a large and unfailing buyer.

Until recently Cyprus wine, which in olden times was so highly famed, had become a neglected industry. In the vinegrowing villages wine was made by natives in their cottages in the most rough and ready fashion for local consumption owly, and the prodnet was of a dark, thiek and heady description. It had also a strong admixture of gypsum as a preservative, which imparted a rongh, coarse flavour. Now there are some 3 or 4 large firms, well equipped with modern winemaking plant, who manufacture a sound, reliable wine of quite a fine quality and at a most moderate price. Superior so called black wine can be had at 4 to 6 copper piastres per oke (quart), and the white variety is usually a trifle more. Some of these wine manufacturers have received recognition at important exhibitions in Europe, which testifies to the excellence of their produce, and every year improvements in their process of manufacture takes place. The largest factory is that at Perapedhi, in the heart of the wine growing district of Limassol, and owned by Messrs. W. H. Chaplin and Co., of London. The produce of this establishment is much sought after locally and also forms the bulk of the exports to London. Perapedhi port, though needing time to mature, is acquiring a good name, and the attention of Egyptian importers might be drawn to this brand and to the other wines and brandies now made by the best Limassol houses.

There are many small commodities which Cyprus should be able to export, but in which, at present, she cannot hope to compete with other countries. Olive trees abound in the Island and yet her methods of cultivation and of oil production remain so crude that, instead of exporting she actually imports a considerable amount. Oils from cotton, linseed and other seeds should also figure in her list of exports, but during the past the poverty of her inhabitants and their ignorance of the use of machinery has up till now kept the door closed against the scientific manufacture of these products. In the course of the next few years they may become staple articles of trade with Egypt.

Turning now to a different category of exports to Egypt, let us briefly review the Cyprus live stock trade. Cypriot mules and donkeys have won their way in public favour in many parts of the world, but in no country are they more highly esteemed than in Egypt. Both are large-framed, handsome animals. A good number of Cyprus mules are now employed in trams and for other traction purposes in Egypt, while both they and Cypriot donkeys are excellent as pack animals, for water-wheels, and for draught purposes generally.

The native pony is a most useful, hardy little beast, averaging about 13 hands, but higher when there has been an admixture of Arab blood. Unfortunately the true Cypriot ponies are becoming very scarce. They are almost entirely monopolized by the mounted police and by the public carriage owners, the latter of whom have become very numerous since the extensive construction of good roads has taken place. The price of all three classes of animals has risen considerably; mules suited to the Egyptian market fetching from £25 to £35; donkeys from £15 to £25; and ponies from £20 to £30.

The native long-tailed sheep is an unattractive looking creature, but is doubtless suited to the country, as it can thrive on the bare herbage which it picks up duringthe summer and which, in many cases, is supplemented by little additional food. Efforts are being made at the Government experimental farm to improve the breed by selection, and a small, though superior flock is now to be found there. Care has been taken to breed only from sheep with pure white fleeces, and the result after three years is that the wool has, this year, realized a good deal above ruling market prices. The quality of mutton is variable and depends largely upon the nature and quantity of the grazing in the locality from which it comes. It may be anticipated that if the cultivation of lucerne and other forage crops continues to extend as it is now doing, the number of sheep and quality of the mutton will improve. The Cypriot is fond of the goat which costs him next to nothing to rear. Goats' skin is largely employed in the manufacture of boots for which it is well suited.

Gypsum is an article of growing importance, and the exports to Egypt are on the increase. Several factories now exist and are doing a good trade. The export of plaster of Paris and of a kind of plaster cement, used in housebuilding, is also extending.

Cyprus can boast of several cigarette factories, the largest of which, that of Messrs Dianello and Vergopoulos at Nicosia, produces cigarettes of the very finest quality. The best brands of Kavallas tobacco are used, and the manufacture and general "get up" is excellent. Owing to the cheapness of rent and labour compared with more advanced countries, the cost of these cigarettes is 'extremely moderate. There is a considerable export of these to England and elsewhere. H. M. King Edward has a consignment regularly sent him.

Certain soils in the Island furnish suitable material for pottery, and a considerable work is done in some villages in the making of pots, jars, tiles and so forth. An expert from Greece has lately been over to instruct the villagers in this art, and it is to be hoped that further steps may be taken in this direction. A large factory exists at Limassol, elaborately equipped on the Marseilles model, for the manufacture of roofing tiles, pipes, bricks etc., and should be capable of doing business on an extensive scale.
Basket and broom making is a minor industry which might well be developed. A good number of baskets find their way to Egypt, but no regular trade can be said to exist at present.

Of recent years the women of Lefkara, Lefkoniko and elsewhere, who make the embroideries known by the name of those villages and which are so justly admired, have discovered a ready market in Egypt where they obtain better prices than in the Island. Covers for beds, and divans of a distinctive and artistic pattern are also made at Phiti.

Bootmaking again is a flourishing and very popular trade, and a good class of boot and shoe to almost any style can be made by the better class makers. Prices range from 8/-to 12/- for ladies, shoes and from 12/-to 15 - for ladies boots, while men's boots cost about the same, and their shoes are 2/-to 3/dearer than the ladies'. There is room for a good trade with Egypt in this commodity.

A considerable stimulus to trade and agriculture has been afforded by the establishment of the Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co. Not only has it acquired several properties in different districts where it is engaged in operations of various kinds, but it has been a large importer of machines and implements and it has thus had a most valuable educative effect upon the native farmers.

The two great requisites-among others for the development of Cypriot trade and agriculture, are water and capital: Where these two are both present, prosperity is almost assured. But they are not often found in combination. The Government is continuing its experiments with artesian boring, and if these should prove successful great hopes will be entertained that agriculture in many of the drier parts will go ahead." A succession of fairly good years has enabled both farmers and shopkeepers to save money, and there is ample evidence that poverty is neither so general nor so acute as it was some years back. The establishment of an Agricultural Bank on the lines of that in Egypt, and of small village cooperative banks in the Papho district should assist in releasing many villagers from the clutches of the usurers. Another factor affecting the financial position of many of the labouring and artizan classes has been the largely increased circulation of money as wages by the Anglo-Egyptian Land Co, and previously for some two or three years in connection with harbour works at Famagusta.

Communication with Egypt is chiefly by means of the weekly mail service, the two mail steamers belonging to the Limassol 8.8. Co. The itinerary, however, permits of only a very short stay at each port, and merchandise is often shipped by other vessels. Imperishable goods have a choice of several lines which intake for Egypt via the Syrian coast. For fruit, vegetables and dairy produce, a fast, direct service, with cold storage is essential, and a regular trade in such articles, as also in meat, game etc., cannot be built up except under such conditions. They present, however, no insuperable difficulties, and private enterprise, aided perhaps by Government, should be able to bring this about. Given cold storage at the Cyprus port,' to which produce could be brought pending embarkation, given a fast service to Port Said with cold storage, and a cold storage depot there, specially reserved for Cyprus goods, perishable produce could be delivered in a fresh condition to the numerous vessels entering and leaving the Canal, and a remunerative trade could be done, capable of holding its own against all-comers.

As has already been remarked, Egypt, although a valuable market, cannot be expected to accept anything and everything that is offered. Shippers must be careful to sendonly the best, and to adopt a rigid system of grading and packing. The enhanced prices Egypt will pay for good, well packed commodities, will amply repay any little extra expense incurred.

At present Cyprus peasants are sadly in the hands of middlemen on both sides of the water. Could they but learn to ship their produce themselves-jointly in bulk-and uniformly packed, and if thoroughly reliable salesmen were appointed in Egypt, all would go well. Perhaps in time this may come about. There are quite a number of Greek Cypriots resident in Egypt, who have made money and still retain an affection for their native land. Could they but realize their opportunities they would assuredly come forward and by their business experience, their wealth and influence, assist their struggling, less enlightened country. men across the water.

div.head: GAS-ENGINES FOR PALESTINE.
div.p: The new gas-engines introduced into Jerusalem and Jaffa are mostly of German manufacture. It is by no means on account of their cheapness that the preference has been given to those of German make, bat for the simple reason that German firms have been more practical in pushing their manufacturers. They employ as agents mechanical engineers who put up the machinery, guarantee its good working for one year, and are able to supply all accessories from their own workshops, thus rendering the task of the native and inexperienced buyer easy and free from anxiety. British firms desirous of securing orders will do well, adds Acting Consul Freeman, to adopt the same method or at least to send out experts to study the requirements of the buyers and prove by facts the superiority of the British-made articles. Under existing conditions they can hardly expect to secure continnons order in this particular class of goods through the ordinary commission agent, or by sending catalogues to possible buyers.

"Some of my friends assure me that Peruna is equally as good for their various ailments as it is for my complaint, but, I do know that for kidney trouble and suffering from a weak back it has no equal."

p.hi: Kidney Trouble Is Not Always Recognized as Catarrh...Pe-ru-na Relieves Kidney Disease because it is a Remedy For All Phases of Catarrh.

div.p: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, before Dr. Hartman began distributing his pamphlets, books and newspaper articles, Bright's Disease of the kidneys was regarded as a disease wholly distinct from catarrh.
Now, Bright's Disease is thought by many the world over to be a phase of catarrhal inflammation.
To relieve Bright's Disease something must be used that has the power to relieve catarrh.
Any medicine that is a remedy for catarrh of one organ is obviously a medicine for catarrh of any other organ.
Pe-ru-na is an internal, systemic catarrh remedy.
Like catarrh, it pervades the whole system, and counteracts the effects of the disease.
A great many people believe that they have been cured of chronic Bright's Disease by the use of Peruna.

hi.hi: It is certainly true that in the earlier stages of Bright's Disease, Peruna is an effective remedy.

div.p: Numerous testimonials on this point establish the fact beyond all doubt.

"I suffered with kidney and bladder trouble until life did not seem worth living. I had tried many medicines, but did not get any relief until I took Peruna. It was really wonderful how much better I was after I used this medicine only a week. At the end of six months I found to my relief that it had rid my system of all poisons and I was cured to stay cured."

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Mardi 4 Juin 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres s'est maintenu hier à 3 3/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a été coté 84 1/8 ex-coupon. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 100. La National Bank a rétrogradé de 1/4 à 22 7/8. L'Agricole a, par contre, avancé de 1/8 à 8 5/8, de même que la Delta Light à 10. La Daïra Sanieh est demeurée inchangée à 15.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est resté invarié à 705, de même que la Banque d'Athènes à 128.

Manque d'entrain, pauvreté des transactions, indécision et lourdeur, se transformant en faiblesse, telles ont été les caractéristiques de la séance de ce matin. Le marché est visiblement dans une période d'expectative. Il attend avec curiosité, sinon avee anxiété, les premiers effets de l'entrée en scène du Syndicat. Or, celui-ci semble s'attarder dans la coulisse, ce qui n'est pas après tout un mauvais indice. Apparemment, ces messieurs du consortium se préparent à faire un début à la fois sûr et brillant.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a réactionné à 22 3 4, l'Agricole à 8 3/8, la Banque d'Athènes à 126-127 et la Cassa di Sconto à 164.

Le Crédit Foncier a été délaissé à 708 ; l'obligation à lots ancienne est remontée à 322 et la nouvelle à 266. La Nile Land s'est inscrite à 21. La part de fondateur Immobilière a été cotée 605 nominal. L'Enterprise and Development a été mieux tenue à 10 3/8-7/16.

La Delta Light s'est raffermie à 10. La part de fondateur Heliopolis a été ramenée à 14. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont perdu 10 francs à 208 ; on sait que l'assemblée générale extraordinaire est fixée à demain.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont fléchi à 18 1/2. Les Upper Egypt sont remontés à 3 1/8. La part de fondateur National Hotel est descendue à P. E. 40.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land a molli à 2 5/16. Les Abdy ont faibli à 0 3/4, les Markets à 23 sh. 3 et les New Egyptian à 17 sh. 4 1/2.
Un journal de Bruxelles émet les appréciations suivantes sur la situation du marché égyptien :

"En présence de la baisse exagérée qui a atteint en ces derniers temps tout le marché égyptien, nous croyons bien faire en attirant l'attention des capitalistes sur les bonnes valeurs traitées anx Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie.

"On sait qu'en Egypte le plus grand facteur de la prospérité du pays a été la culture du coton qui, grâce aux travaux méthodiques effectués en ces dernières années, a vu sa production s'accroître dans des proportions extraordinaires. Comme la qualité du coton égyptien est unique, cette augmentation de production n'a nullement influencé les prix dans un sens défavorable ; bien au contraire, le coton, qui était il y a deux ans à 12 talaris le *cantar, valait l'année dernière environ 16 talaris au début de la campagne et s'établit cette année à 20 talaris. On prévoit pour cette année une augmentation d'agréage de 10% et comme la récolte s'annonce favorablement, on pent *compter que les rentrées d'or en Egypte seront d'environ 30 % supérieures à celles de l'année passée.

"La circulation d'or, la richesse du pays sont donc appelées à augmenter et le marché financier aura par conséquent l'élément nécessaire pour prendre un nouvel essor. C'est ce qui nous donne la conviction que l'on peut en ce moment s'intéresser aux titres égyptiens avec de très réelles chances de bénéfice ; en faisant une bonne sélection on évitera même tout risque de mécompte."

"La crise que les Bourses égyptiennes tro. versent a pour cause des maladresses et des erreurs rendues presque inévitables lorsqu'un pays tel que l'Egypte passe rapidement de la pauvreté à l'opulence. En réalité, les cours actuels des titres résultent de la situation boursière et non de la marche des affaires sociales, qui, on peut l'affirmer, n'ont pas été atteintes. Aussi bien les résultats à venir ont de très sérieuses chances d'être supérieurs à ceux obtenus jusqu'ici. La situation de l'Egypte est aussi solide que jamais , nous n'hésitons donc pas à dire que les cours des meilleures valeurs sont ridiculement bas."

On annonce de Bruxelles la formation d'une Société anonyme sous la dénomination de " Compagnie Égyptienne Thomson-Houston." Elle a pour objet la fabrication et l'exploitation de tous appareils et machines du système Thomson-Houston ou tous autres systèmes si appliquant ou utilisant l'énergie électrique
Le capital social est de 5 millions de francs, représenté par 10,000 actions de Frs. 500. II a été, en outre, créé 6,000 parts de fondateur sans valeur nominale.
Le premier conseil d'administration est composé de MM. C. Achillopoulo, C. Aghion, H. Bousquet, Chi. Burrel, Charley Burton, E. Coze, V. Fris, R. Lagout, C. Nicolaïdi et E. Thurnauer.

Suivant des informations de Paris, le dividende de la Banque Impériale Ottomane pour 1906 serait de Frs. 22.50. Ce chiffre peut être considéré comme très vraisemblable; toutefois il ne saurait avoir encore rien d'officiel, car l'assemblée générale ordinaire qui fixera cette répartition ne se réunit que vers la fin du mois courant. Quoi qu'il en soit, cette répartition n'absorberait que Prs. 11,250,000 sur le bénéfice de 19,000,000, ce qui permettrait de doter largement les fonds de prévoyance.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Par décision du conseil d'administration de la Banque d'Escompte et de Reports d'Egypte et du Soudan, les 3ème et 4ème versements, à raison de £ 1 chacun, sur les actions de cette Société devront être effectués au plus tard le 24 Juin et le 24 Août 1907 au siège social au Caire ou à la Banque d'Orient à Alexan. drie.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de For
div.p: de l'Etat Égyptien
AVIS
L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au 15 Juin
1907, à midi, des offres pour l'achat des | figues de barbarie produites le long de la voie ferrée entre Tewfik Ieh et Saft-El-Melouk.
Chaque soumissionnaire doit joindre à son offre un récépissé de versement de LE. 5 à titre de dépôt provisoire.
Les offres seront valables pendant 15 jours à partir de la date fixée pour la remise des soumissions.
Chaque offre devra être accompagnée d'une | feuille de papier timbré de 30 m/m. Elle devra
être adressée par la poste sous pli recommandé à : Monsieur de Directeur Général des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat,

Le Caire. et sous double enveloppe, intérieure portant | la suscription : "Offre pour achat de figues de barbarie entre Tewfik Ieh et Saft-el-Melouk." Toute offre reçue après la date et l'heure ci dessus fixées ne sera pas prise en considération. I L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la plus élevée ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées, et elle se réserve le | droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 27 Mai 1907. 30374-2-21
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de st | l'Etat informe le Public qu'un examen aura lieu le 12 Juin prochain et les jours suivant s'il y a lieu à 10 heures du matin, au Service Central de la Voie, pour deux emplois d'Agents des Domaines, au Bureau de l'Ingénieur Divisionnaire de la Voie et des Travaux, à Assiout (Haute-Egypte). La paie de début sera de L. Eg. 8 par mois.

Les candidats, qui doivent être de nationalité égyptienne et possesseurs, au moins, du certificat d'études primaires, devront présenter leurs demande et titres à Mr. l'Ingénieur en Chef de la Voie et des Travaux, au Caire, avant le 9 Juin 1907.
La priorité sera donnée aux candidats possédant le diplôme de sortie de l'Ecole des Arts et Métiers et à ceux connaissant une langue étrangère (anglais ou français).
Le Caire, le 31 Mars 1907: 30405-2-1
AVIB

L'Administration des Chemins de fer et Télégraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public qu'un bureau télégraphique a été ouvert à Marsa Matrouh le ler courant, pour l'échange de télégrammes en | langues Européennes et Arabe.
L'horaire de ce bureau est de 8 a.m. à 1 p.m. et de 3 p.m. à 8 p.m.; les Dimanches de 8 a.m. à 10 a.m. et de 5 p. m. à 6 p.m.
Le Caire, le 1er Juin 1907. 30410-2-2
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de fer et l: Télégraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du public que le bureau télégraphique de San Stefano est ouvert pour l'échange de télégrammes en langues Européennes et Arabe, de 8 a m. à 1.30 p.m. et de 3.30 pm. à 8 p.m.
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de fer et Télégraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du public qu'à partir du ler Juin prochain, le bureau télégraphique de Gezireh sera ouvert de 8 a.m. à 1 p.m et de 3 p.m, à 6 p.m. et les dimanches de 8 a.m. à 1 p.m. seulement.
Le Caire, le 28 Mai 1907. 30390-2-2
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public que le bureau télégraphique de Bulkeley est ouvert pour l'échange des télégrammes en langues Européennes et Arabe de 8 a.m. à 1.30 p.m. et de 3.30 p m. à 8 p.m.
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public qu'à partir de ce jour, le bureau télégraphique de Hélouan sera ouvert de 8 a.m. à 1 p.m. et de 3 p.m. à 8 p.m.
Le Caire, le 1er Juin 1907. 30412-2-2

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6.
